{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3581951,"name":"Kade Dressing","username":"Kade","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T02:05:09.796Z","cooked":"

After this season, my team and I were 100% not pleased with our wiring and want to improve it for the following years. However, we (I) want to know how others deal with wire management as well as making their wiring look pretty, while still being easily accessible.

A quick rundown of our wiring:
We used heat shrink to keep moving wires hooked together to prevent wire entanglement in our chains, however, anytime we had a CAN issue, we’d have to cut into it to access it, and it took wayyyy too long.
Other wires on our robot were tangled at some points, and there were a lot of connection ppints using WAGO’s or other connector pieces because we had to continuously use multiple sections of wire cause we didnt have long rolls (we plan on getting some rolls in the future)

But I was looking into nylon wraps and stuff, as well as some different wires. The reason why I was looking into wires is because during our Belton comp, the inspector told us that we were still using old wire that is a lot harder to deal with, and a lot of other teams use new wire, and I didn’t, and still don’t know what type of wire he was talking about.

If any of you have any suggestions, or happen to know what type of wire he was talking about, I’d be very thankful.

Split loom sleeving is great for this. Absolute game changer for our team this season.

+1 on the sleeving.

We used that very heavily on our robot for the baseplate this year.

image939×638 125 KB

(before)

image769×716 107 KB

We also like to use this (not this specific brand) cable sleeving for some of our smaller wires (think CAN, 18AWG power to CANCoders, Pigeons, etc), to help keep them together.

Kade:

If any of you have any suggestions, or happen to know what type of wire he was talking about, I’d be very thankful.

Without knowing the exact wording, it could just be that your wire is old and crusty and is hard to bend. We actually got new wire this year from PowerWerx, and we have been very happy with both the quality, and the flexibility.

Kade:

and there were a lot of connection ppints using WAGO’s or other connector pieces

I highly recommend learning to solder for CAN and 18AWG cables (please dont solder 12AWG). We switched to soldering everything this year, and we never had an electrical problem at all during any of our competitions. It also makes CAN runs easier since you don’t have a massive connector in the way.

I also am a big fan of Anderson Powerpoles, especially when you put a ziptie through the holes in the connector to zip-tie them together, makes it bulletproof.

My personal tip for cable management is try to keep bundles together, typically with zipties. You also want to make sure that you are properly strain relieving wires so they don’t become unplugged.

For example, we had our cable runs all zip tied together that way they can help to not only support each other, but also stay in one spot together, making the entire bundle easier to route.

image444×615 42.9 KB

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":104,"updated_at":"2025-04-07T02:36:42.144Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":770,"readers_count":769,"score":164.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":498210,"topic_slug":"wire-management","display_username":"Kade Dressing","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53274,"username":"EmerqldWither","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerqldwither/{size}/226176_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wire-management/498210/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3582030,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T03:28:29.527Z","cooked":"
Kade:

we had to continuously use multiple sections of wire cause we didnt have long rolls

Everyone’s focusing on the split loom nylon protectors (which is absolutely what you should do), but this right here is definitely your biggest issue, and I’m glad you know you need to solve it. You’ve taken a wire that should have, 2 points of failure (at either end) and added several more in between. No wonder you had to keep cutting apart your heat shrink to get at each individual section.

We did this in 2023 when we weren’t properly motivated to wire things correctly, and it cost us match after match. Given how expensive regionals, travel, and the robot are, each match it happened in was wasted money. We absolutely should have just bought longer CAN wires. We did a total revamp of our wiring and connectors, and if you’re interested, here’s a writeup on our OA about how we converted to using a lot of rally sport wires and connectors, and in 2 years we’ve never had a wiring issue in a match. Personally, I’m not a fan of soldering; yes it works very well, but if you don’t do it right (like say, if you are a student who is new to soldering) then a bad solder is a timebomb waiting to give you trouble, but you won’t know until it happens because checking for a bad solder is really difficult.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":104,"updated_at":"2025-04-07T03:33:27.316Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":759,"readers_count":758,"score":251.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498210,"topic_slug":"wire-management","display_username":"Nick Foote","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2102-build-thread-2024-25-open-alliance/476375/3","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"2102 Build Thread 2024-25 Open Alliance","clicks":44}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8103,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student"},"post_url":"/t/wire-management/498210/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3582083,"name":"Kade Dressing","username":"Kade","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T04:09:54.189Z","cooked":"

We did also have problems with soldering, and I didnt have enough time to figure it out so I went back to ferrel connectors and wagos, but the reason we didnt have long enough strands of wire is because of our prior year members and our district.

(This is just a bit of backstory, you dont need to read it if you dont want to. Second to last paragraph has the bit you really need to read)

Our prior year members were very ignorant and didnt try to figure out new things, for instance, our old programming lead didnt really know how to code the robot himself, he had to rely on other teams code. Our build team just used templates and built them wrong, and our wiring was cheap because we had almost no funding and no one focused on wiring.

This year, I am programming lead, and I learned almost everything i need to learn to have a successful season with coding then taught it to the rest of the members on my team, and at the same time, due to the ignorance of our prior members, they didnt really do a good job at keeping track of things and also broke everything, so we had not enough wires this year and didnt have enough time to order any because every time we want to purchase something, we have to get permission from the district, which takes about 2 weeks, and then we have to wait for the order to come in. We almost couldnt compete this year because all of our rios were fried from previous years and by the time the district finally approved our order, they were all sold out. We also need a new computer, but the district wont let us get one unless they put administrative protection on it, removing our access to use driver station and stuff, so we cant get a new comouter, so we had to use mine instead.

And since the season is over, im trying to make the best effort to turn around our situation and completely go through all our electrical components, organize them, figure out what we do and dont need, and then finally rewire all our robot(s) to make them look and work pretty. But yes, i completely agree that that was 100% one of our biggest problems and im not proud of it in any way. Im probably going to use what everyone has said and ensure i stick to using one strand of wire between motors and other electrical components, and make sure I use nylon wraps to keep them stored safely.

This may have sounded really rude (i know thats kinda how i read it), but in no way was it meant to be, i just kinda went on a rant and it ended up sounded a little worse than i wanted it to be. But thank you for your help.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":104,"updated_at":"2025-04-07T04:09:54.189Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":715,"readers_count":714,"score":193.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":498210,"topic_slug":"wire-management","display_username":"Kade Dressing","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":8103,"username":"Footie","name":"Nick Foote","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wire-management/498210/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3582111,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T04:27:37.392Z","cooked":"

I’m sorry to hear you’ve been going through so much trouble. Purchasing is definitely one of the most pain in the butt processes any team (or anyone at a company) goes through. For many years I’ve just been buying things for the team and not getting reimbursed because I considered it less of a pain to just eat the cost. Finally this year I bought some stuff for the team that was expensive enough that it became worth it to get reimbursed, but man was it a pain when you involve a school foundation and ASB.

While for your team, it makes sense to buy a spool of nice wire for $50-$100 because a single match costs $400+ to compete in, and dying in that match is wasting that money, it can be hard to explain that to a school finance admin. If it takes so long to purchase things, you really should make a point of purchasing as much as you can in the Fall. Regardless of the game, you’re gonna need CAN wire.

I wish you luck with procuring some new wires and electronics.

Hint about the driver station: ask a sponsor if they have any laptops they can donate (many will be getting rid of perfectly fine laptops that just aren’t Windows 11 compatible), and just never tell the school about that computer so it doesn’t get locked down (yes, I am in favor of breaking school rules that I think are stupid and aren’t safety related).

What problems did you have with your CAN+wago? We did that last year and had no failures. Note we did use appropriate gauge ferrules, which is a must due to the small wire (22ga). Wire needs to be strain relieved. Of course, it still has to be done correctly - a common initial error was for to not have the wire all the way to the end of the ferrule. This year we went to Molex-SL, which is a modest amount more work and skill required initially, but is a smaller (and nearly inconsequentially faster, easier to connect) connector.

We used solder seal wire connectors for the first time this year and they will be on our robots in the future. They were mostly used for making short CAN branches for each motor controller as a precaution so the whole bus would still work if something went wrong in one. I think we had zero CAN issues over 3 events. I also recommend upgrading to Thrifty Nova CAN cables as a replacement if you are using SPARK MAX. The robot had hot glue on every connector that plugs in(no worries–it comes off easily with alcohol).

We love using adhesive cable tie mounts, McMaster slit corrugated tubing, and braided sleeving. We also plan wire routing during the design process to sure we our designs are electrically friendly and incorporate cable tie mounts in 3d printed parts. This allows us to be really efficient when wiring and have a step by step plan with prepped (one end crimped, one end uncrimped with slack) wires.

Kade:

We also need a new computer, but the district wont let us get one unless they put administrative protection on it, removing our access to use driver station and stuff, so we cant get a new comouter, so we had to use mine instead.

If you really need to, maybe you can ask your tech department to allow you to connect on certain ports and IP’s, and give admin access on the driver station (to be clear, you would do this for at home development, at comp you should use a laptop with full admin access).

An example, the tech team could be allowing access to 10.TE.AM.* range of IP’s (your typical IP address range used for the RoboRIO, Radio, and most co-processors), 172.22.11.2 (RoboRIO USB IP) and also allow the ports as outlined in the game manual at R704 and port 22 for SSH access. But obviously, this is an unideal setup, but if it means that you can use a more powerful laptop for development and a comp laptop, it could be a solution.
